questions.question_text: Which command do you enter to permit IPv6 functionality on an EIGRPv3 interface?

comments.content: B sets the asn for router to conf the r id and for interface its D

discussion.content:
B. Router1(config-if)#ipv6 router eigrp 1
Answer B

choices.D: Unlike distance-vector routing protocols, link-state routing protocols send routing-table updates to neighbors only after adjacency is established.
choices.A: Unlike distance-vector routing protocols, link-state routing protocols can cause routing loops.
choices.C: Distance-vector routing protocols use more memory than link-state routing protocols.
choices.B: Distance-vector routing protocols converge more quickly than link-state routing protocols.

questions.question_text: Which three statements about QoS policing are true? (Choose three.)

choices.A: It can be applied to outbound traffic only.
choices.F: It is configured in bits per second.
choices.D: It can be applied to inbound and outbound traffic.

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/quality-of-service-qos/qos-policing/19645-policevsshape.html

Traffic policing is Configured in bytes.

questions.question_text: Which command do you enter to configure local authentication for PPP on a Cisco device?

discussion.content:
None of those answers are correct. PVST+ is based on 802.1D not s, so it can't be B and RPVST+ is based on 802.1w so it can't be A either.

Both RPVST+ and PVST+ are Cisco Proprietary. 

RPVST+ is faster to converge than PVST+

I suspect there is a typo and B should say PVST+ is based on 802.1D

choices.A: RPVST+ is based on 802.1D and PVST+ is based on 802.1s.
choices.D: Only PVST+ includes Cisco proprietary standards.
choices.B: RPVST+ is based on 802.1w and PVST+ is based on 802.1s.
choices.C: RPVST+ has slower convergence than PVST+.

questions.question_text: Which difference between PVST+ and RPVST+ is true?
